_prev_prog_3.Description:
1.  The 2 - 17,500 gallon ammonia storage tanks are tied together by a common header.  Fill levels of each tank will be limited to 85% of the total volume or 15,000 gallons each.  This will all for thermal expansion of the liquid caused by ambient heat gain.  High alarm is set at 80% level.



2.  All of the ammonia equipment is located outside, with the exception of two application points in the Granulation Building.



3.  Pressure reduction valves, pressure indication, flow meters and flow control valves are all installed in the system.  These instruments are continually monitored by the DCS system. 



4.  All components exposed to ammonia liquid and gas are fabricated with steel or stainless steel for corrosion resistance.



5.  Electrical classification for the ammonia system is NEMA 4X, watertight and corrosion resistant.



6   All employees will be trained in Hazwhoper 24 Hour First Responder.



7.  The perimeter of the facility is fenced and manned 24 hours/day.



8.  Gates located at the two vehicle and one rail entrance to the site have been installed to prevent unauthorized entry.



9.  Outdoor lighting provided to monitor the plant.



10.  Employee entrance allowed via a security swipe card.



11.  The ammonia storage tanks and pumps are placed in a secondary fenced area with lockable gates.



12.  Employee and visitor parking is provided outside the gate to the process area and adjacent to the entrance guard station.



13.  All Process Safety Management (PSM) program elements will be followed for this system.



14. SCBA's have been provided for Emergency Response.



15.  Procedures for additional external hazards have been created.  Hurricanes, floods, tornados, bomb threats, power outages, etc.



16.  Ammonia mitigation systems have been installed:

    a)  Fogging water supply on top of tanks and equipment

    b)  Remotely activated pull cables for emergency manual valves located 15' away in opposite directions.

    c)  Set of 4 pressure relief valves on each storage tank

    d)  High-High, High, Low, Low-Low alarms installed on each storage tank for level and pressure.

    e)  Safety shower installed at the ammonia tanks

    f)  Redundant Ammonia vapor sensors installed near storage tanks to monitor for leaks. 

    g)  Maintenance valve for nitrogen purge.

    h)  Vapor lines are vented to a water scrubber tank

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Anuvia Zellwood facility is located at 6751 West Jones Avenue, Zellwood, Florida.  The facility sits on 62 acres of agricultural land that was purchased for the construction of an ammonium sulfate fertilizer and soil nutrient manufacturing facility.  



At the Anuvia Zellwood facility, only the operations related to the handling and consumption of anhydrous ammonia is covered by the RMP Program.  NOTE:  This site maintains amounts of anhydrous ammonia greater than the 10,000 pound RMP threshold quantity.



Starting with the ammonia truck unloading, the RMP Covered Process includes the 2 - 17,500 gallon ammonia storage tanks, the ammonia truck transfer pumping unit, the ammonia pump set (PU-1518 and PU-1519), the ammonia flow control skid, Ammonia vaporizer (VP-1703), and all ammonia transfer piping and instruments.  Consult the Ammonia Equipment (RMP Equipment) List for details. 



This facility is regulated as Program 3 site of the EPA RMP regulations 40 CFR Part 68.



Offsite consequence analysis has been performed for the Ammonia process using EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis.  The Worst Case Scenario (WCS) has been identified as 3.2 miles and the Alternate Case Scenario (ACS) has been identified as 0.2 miles.  The WCS and ACS are included with the Risk Management Program submitted to the RMP*eSubmit.  A copy of this submittal is kept in the Plant Managers Office.  Off site Consequence Analysis will be updated any time a process change will increase the affect of a Worst Case release.  See 40 CFR Part 68 for details on RMP Plan revisions.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention:

The Anuvia Plant has taken numerous precautionary and prevention steps to minimize potential failures of the ammonia system.  Redundant safety systems, vapor monitoring equipment, security procedures, mechanical integrity inspections, shutdown and water spray system.  The Plant is manned 24 hours per

day and systems are inspected on an hourly basis.  Any changes to the system will be tracked and documented in accordance with the Management of Change procedures under OSHA Process Safety Management standard.



Five Year accident History:

Since this facility is being built and is a new process, there have not been any accidents in the past 5 years.



Emergency Response Program:

The Emergency Response Plan has been developed by Anuvia to protect human health and the environment in the event of an unintended release of hazardous materials, personal injury or property damage accidents, fire, natural Events (Tornados, Hurricanes, Floods, etc.) and/or explosion.  The plan and procedures are formalized to include an assessment of actual or potential hazards to human health or the environment, provide record keeping procedures of emergency incidents, and describe the reporting of emergency incidents to regulatory agencies.  This plan also formalizes the arrangements with local police, fire departments, hospitals, and emergency response personnel in case of an emergency event.  The Emergency Response Plan also describes the actions that facility personnel must take in response to fires, explosions, or any unplanned, sudden, or non-sudden release of hazardous materials or hazardous materials constituents to air, soil, or surface water at the facility. The Plan also describes the available emergency equipment, training, evacuation and shelter in place procedures, and emergency shutdown procedures.  A copy of this plan is available to each employee and is intended to meet the mandates of the applicable regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over this facility.



Planned changes to improve safety:

Since the Anuvia facility is a new manufacturing site, all available safety systems and Best Manufacturing Practices were implemented prior to and during construction.  Any future safety, control equipment, technology organizational changes or mitigation will be addressed usi
ng the Management of Change procedures or addressed in the next Process Hazard Analysis.
